bank.title: VecIt! Vector and Multivariable Calculus
bank.outcomes:
Surfaces and Graphs N1 outcomes/N1
Use traces and contours to describe surfaces in three-space that are graphs of two-variable functions and level sets of three-variable functions, including quadric surfaces.
Vector Arithmetic N2 outcomes/N2
Perform and geometrically interpret sums, differences, scalar multiples, and magnitudes of vectors in n-dimensional space.
Vector Geometry N3 outcomes/N3
Choose among, and use, dot products and cross products of vectors to compute quantities of geometric interest, including angles and areas.
Parametrized Lines N4 outcomes/N4
Determine parametric equations for a line in three-space, given sufficient information to determine a point and a direction vector.
Planes N5 outcomes/N5
Determine a level set equation for a plane in three-space defined either by a point and a normal vector, or by three given non-collinear points.
Parameterized Curve NA outcomes/NA
Sketch and parameterize portions of oriented curves, including those defined by intersections of surfaces and those which involve circular motions.
Derivatives and Curvature NB outcomes/NB
Use derivatives to determine, and distinguish among, a parameterized curve’s tangent, speed, velocity, and acceleration.
-->
Partial Derivative Computations D1 outcomes/D1
Compute the partial derivatives of a given multivariable function, up to second order.
Tangent Planes D2 outcomes/D2
Find equations for tangent planes to surfaces expressed as graphs of two-variable functions and as level sets of three-variable functions.
The Gradient of f(x,y) D3 outcomes/D3 Compute the gradient vector of a two-variable function, give its geometric interpretation with respect both to the contours of the function and to its graph, and use it to calculate directional derivatives in a given direction.
Critical Points of Multivariable Functions D4 outcomes/D4 Use its gradient vector to locate critical points of a multivariable function, and its second-order partial derivatives to classify critical points as local maximum, local minimum, saddle points, or degenerate.
Multivariable Limits DA outcomes/DA
Use continuity and polar-coordinate methods to calculate limits of multivariable functions, and use multiple-approach methods to demonstrate when such a limit does not exist.
Partial Derivative Interpretations DB outcomes/DB
Carefully interpret the first- and second-order partial derivatives of a multivariable function as slopes and concavities of its graph’s traces.
Multivariable Chain Rule DC outcomes/DC
Identify all routes of composition when two or more multivariable functions are composed, and use the multivariable chain rule to compute such a function’s partial derivatives.
The Gradient of f(x,y,z) DD outcomes/DD
Compute the gradient vector of a three-variable function, give its geometric interpretation with respect to its level surfaces, and use it to calculate directional derivatives in a given direction.
Optimization and Extreme Values of Multivariable Functions DE outcomes/DE
Use both critical points and a parametrization of its boundary to find absolute maximum and minimum values of a multivariable function on a closed and bounded domain.
Constrained Optimization DF outcomes/DF
Use Lagrange multipliers to determine absolute maximum and minimum values of a multivariable function subject to one or more constant constraints.
Differentiability DG outcomes/DG
Prove or disprove that a continuous function is differentiable.
The "Tape-Measure" Method S1 outcomes/S1 Describe a given region in the xy-plane using coordinate inequalities, in at least two distinct ways.
Double Integrals S2 outcomes/S2 Set up and evaluate double integrals over general regions, using iterated integrals with "tape-measured" bounds.
Double Integrals in Polar Coordinates SA outcomes/SA
Use polar coordinates to transform the integrand, the bounds, and the area element of a given double integral.
Surface Area SB outcomes/SB
Set up double integrals to compute surface areas of portions of parametrized surfaces.
Triple Integrals SC outcomes/SC
Set up and evaluate triple integrals over general regions, using iterated integrals and “tape-measured” bounds.
Change of Variables SD1 outcomes/SD1
Use change of variables and come up with a better description.
Triple Integrals in Cylindrical and Spherical Coordinates SD2 outcomes/SD2
Use cylindrical and spherical coordinates to transform the integrand, the bounds, and the volume element of a given triple integral.
Applications of Multiple Integrals SE outcomes/SE
Use double and triple integrals to solve applied problems involving mass, density, and probability.
-->
Vector Fields V1 outcomes/V1 Sketch and identify vector fields in two and three dimensions, including gradient vector fields of two- and three-variable functions.
Line Integral Computation V2 outcomes/V2 Directly compute the line integral of a vector field over a given oriented path.
Gradient Vector Fields V3 outcomes/V3 Classify a given vector field as gradient (or not), find scalar potential functions for gradient fields, and apply the fundamental theorem of calculus for path-independent line integrals.
Green's Theorem V4 outcomes/V4 Identify when Green’s Theorem may be applied to find the total circulation of a vector field along a closed path, and use the Theorem to carry out this computation using a double integral.
Line Integral Heuristics VA outcomes/VA Predict from a sketch whether a given line integral of a vector field along an oriented path is positive, negative, or zero.
Path-Independent Integrals VB outcomes/VB Identify when the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals may be applied, and use the Theorem to compute line integrals using a scalar potential function.
Curl of a Vector Field VC outcomes/VC Compute the scalar curl of a two-dimensional vector field and the vector curl of a three-dimensional vector field. Use notions of circulation to predict whether the scalar curl of a given two-dimensional vector field is positive, negative, or zero. .
Divergence of a Vector Field VD outcomes/VD Compute the divergence of a vector field, and use notions of flux to predict whether the divergence of a given vector field is positive, negative, or zero. .
Flux Integrals VE outcomes/VE Directly compute the flux integral of a vector field through a given oriented surface. .
Stokes and Divergence Theorems VF outcomes/VF dentify when a flux integral calculation may be made simpler through the application of Stokes’ Theorem (resp. Divergence Theorem), and use the appropriate Theorem to carry out this computation using a line integral (resp. triple integral). .
